At 19:17 30/09/2005, you wrote:
>Out of curiosity, and to spark debate,
>
>how can this (below) be expanded to include the general case of a
>generalized device that is capable of 'learning' and developing it's
>own strategy?  That is, it 'learns' the rules, it develops a strategy,
>and some of what is 'learned' in one game is transferrable to another
>game.
>
>Or is that not the ultimate goal?

Yes it is.  _An_ ultimate goal anyway :)

If you refer to the work that Derek was reporting seeing at GECCO, then I 
don't think it does directly contribute to this ultimate goal.

OTOH, I do still have this in the back of my mind as an eventual objective 
of my SLEAT work.

Or rather, I started with this objective in mind, and then I pruned and 
simplified it until it became a small enough piece of work for me to start 
on today...  And what I arrived at was SLEAT.

TicTacToe is really only a simple test case for this approach.  A suitable 
model system for prototyping.  Once I have things working nicely for TTT, 
my plan is then to try and apply the same approach to more complex games.

This might then begin to support transfer between different games.  e.g. 
the set of intermediate boards that I generate could provide a means for 
otherwise incompatible chromosomes to talk to one-another.  Things are not 
yet so abstracted that the geometry of the board can be separated from the 
rules of the game.  e.g. TTT chromosomes will transfer far better into Go 
that chess, because TTT and Go share the concept of "yours and my pieces", 
whereas chess extends that in a more complex manner due to their being six 
different types of piece on either side...

>What if you were to attempt to evolve a network that is capable of
>playing 10 different games?  Chess.  Checkers, Go, tic-tac-toe, and
>who knows how many others.  The search space would be impossibly
>large, and perhaps even impossible to traverse.  The only possible
>solution would be a generalized learning mechanism, wouldn't it?  But
>would we ever find it?

         Ian

In fifteen minutes, everybody will be in the future.
